title: Tiny but Mighty: Parasitoids vs.¬†Wheat Stem Sawfly
text:
This Facebook post from the Montana Wheat and Barley Committee highlights how tiny parasitoid wasps are helping combat the wheat stem sawfly, a major pest in Montana grain systems. I helped write the scientific background for the post and took the featured photograph.
Photo by Jackson Strand.

title: Master‚Äôs Thesis Defense
text:
I successfully defended my Master‚Äôs thesis at Montana State University on August 19, 2024. My research focused on the agroecological role of smooth brome (Bromus inermis) in supporting native parasitoids of the wheat stem sawfly (Cephus cinctus), with a particular emphasis on agro- and chemical ecology.

 View My Slides 

You can view the video recording of my defense here:

title: 2023 LRES Student Research Symposium
text:
I presented this talk at the 2023 LRES Student Research Symposium in Bozeman, MT, where I received 1st place in the oral presentation competition. The presentation focused on how organic volatile compounds mediate interactions between wheat stem sawfly, its braconid parasitoids, and smooth brome.

 View Slides 


üìç Location: Bozeman, MT
üìÖ Date: Monday, April 14, 2023
üïï Time: 6:20 ‚Äì 6:32 PM





2023 LRES Symposium winners!

title: Entomology 2022
text:
I presented this talk at the 2022 Entomological Society of America (ESA) Annual Meeting in Vancouver, BC. This presentation explored how organic volatile compounds can be used to understand ecological interactions among the wheat stem sawfly, its parasitoids, and the non-crop grass smooth brome.

 View Slides 


üìç Location: Vancouver, BC, Canada
üìÖ Date: Monday, November 14, 2022
üïê Time: 12:18 ‚Äì 12:30 PM

title: Entomology 2023
text:
I presented this talk at the 2023 Entomological Society of America (ESA) Annual Meeting in National Harbor, MD. This presentation extended my previous work on wheat stem sawfly‚Äìparasitoid‚Äìgrass interactions, using organic volatile compounds to infer ecological relationships. It was awarded 2nd place in the ESA Student Competition.

 View Slides 


üìç Location: National Harbor, MD
üìÖ Date: Thursday, November 16, 2023
üïê Time: 12:18 ‚Äì 12:30 PM





Accepting my 2nd place award!

title: South Dakota Trip (Spearfish) - September 2025
text:
Weather



üå¶Ô∏è High 70s, cloudy, some drizzle in the morning. Sooooo many mosquitos ü¶ü.
We left Aberdeen on Wednesday morning at 7 AM. We stopped by the Brown County Weed Control garage to grab our cages that they kindly took down for us in July. Thanks Chris!!
After getting to the Spearfish area on Wednesday afternoon, we visited our Sawyer site to collect data from the M. janthinus transects. On Thursday, we visited Nemo to collect both grid data and transect data from the site.

‚õÖ Low 60s, partly sunny. Got pretty toasty towards the end.


I drove out to Hog Hollow to complete the setup of all Rhinusa pilosa exclosure grid sites for Spring 2025. title: Elk Park and Badger Gulch - May 2025
text:
Weather



‚õÖ Low 50s, partly sunny. Cool and pleasant with occasional sunbreaks.


Eric, Aden, and I drove back out to Elk Park to finish up building the exclosure fence. We then drove over to Badger Gulch for our first visit of 2025 to retrieve weather data and install the trail cameras.

Elk Park




We had leftover fencing from our South Dakota trip (exactly the right amount!) so we used that to wrap around the entire Elk Park exclosure. I also retreived images from the trail cameras I set up during our last visit on May 8, 2025.
Site activities

Finish building exclosure
Add stakes to control grid where slash piles make road hares unusable
Retrieve preliminary images from trail cameras






Eric & Aden building exclosure fence






Completed Elk Park exclosure






Eric and Aden add stakes to control grid






Badger Gulch




We previously set up the exclosure at Badger Gulch in November of 2024. We returned to the site to retrieve data logger data as well as set up the trail cameras.

title: Horse Gulch Stem Collection - Fall 2024
text:
Weather



üå§Ô∏è Low 40s, mostly sunny. Brisk with occasional clouds.


Eric, Sharlene, and I drove out to the site of the 2024 Horse Gulch Fire just north of Canyon Ferry Lake in Montana. We collected stems from four different sites along the roadway, trying to pick adjacent areas of burned and unburned.
Historical monitoring sites exist in this area for Dalmatian toadflax biocontrol using Mecinus janthiniformis.
  

Click to expand and view the whole map.

More information on the 2024 Horse Gulch Fire can be found here.
Sites:

Coxcy Gulch
Neversweats Gulch
Hunters Gulch
Kingsberry Gulch

title: Agroecological importance of smooth brome‚Ä¶
text:
Agroecological importance of smooth brome in managing wheat stem sawfly (Hymenoptera: Cephidae) via associated braconid parasitoids
Authors: Jackson R. Strand, Robert K.D. Peterson, Tracy M. Sterling, David K. Weaver
Journal: Economic Entomology
DOI: 10.1093/jee/toae246
Abstract: Wheat stem sawfly (WSS), Cephus cinctus Norton (Hymenoptera: Cephidae), is a major pest of cereal crops throughout the Northern Great Plains of North America. Native parasitoids, Bracon cephi (Gahan) and B. lissogaster Muesebeck (Hymenoptera: Braconidae), play a key role in suppressing WSS populations and limiting associated damage. Smooth brome grass (Bromus inermis Leyss.) serves as a potential trap reservoir for WSS when grown in areas surrounding wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) fields in Montana. Its unique biology allows it to support high WSS infestation while promoting significant larval mortality throughout the growing season. Late-season WSS survivors can then serve as hosts for WSS parasitoids. Our study investigated smooth brome as a host refuge for WSS parasitoids. We measured WSS larval infestation and survival rate inside smooth brome grown within WSS-inclusion cages, finding a maximum infestation of 66.5% and an end-of-year WSS survival of 5.7%. In addition, we collected stems from sites in central and north-central Montana to measure the WSS infestation and parasitoid prevalence in wheat and adjacent smooth brome. WSS infestation was high in both Big Sandy (64.5% smooth brome, 65.7% adjacent wheat) and Moccasin, MT (50.6%, 38.6%). Year-end WSS larval mortality was 43.6% greater in smooth brome compared to adjacent wheat at both field sites, but both hosted similar numbers of WSS parasitoids. This research underscores the importance of smooth brome in providing a sustainable host refuge for WSS parasitoids and highlights its significant role in supporting the economics of wheat cultivation.

title: Sensory and behavioral responses of braconid parasitoids‚Ä¶
text:
Sensory and behavioral responses of braconid parasitoids to changes in volatile emissions induced by wheat stem sawfly (Hymenoptera: Cephidae) larval feeding in winter wheat and smooth brome
Authors: Jackson R. Strand, Oscar G. Perez Moya, Robert K.D. Peterson, Tracy M. Sterling, David K. Weaver
Journal: Insect Science
DOI: 10.1093/jisesa/ieaf016
Abstract: The wheat stem sawfly, Cephus cinctus Norton, is a major pest of cultivated wheat (Triticum aestivum L.) and other cereals in North America. The native congeneric parasitoids Bracon cephi (Gahan) and B. lissogaster Muesebeck are important biocontrol agents and play a crucial role in managing wheat stem sawfly outbreaks and damage. Smooth brome grass (Bromus inermis Leyss) has been found to be an effective wheat stem sawfly sink and parasitoid source when grown in areas neighboring wheat fields in Montana. To better understand the ecology of the system, we investigated both the wheat stem sawfly-induced volatile organic compounds produced by smooth brome and winter wheat, and the electrophysiological and behavioral response of B. cephi and B. lissogaster to the collected volatiles via coupled electroantennography and gas chromatography-flame ionization detection. Volatile concentration analysis indicated significantly increased production of (Z)-3-hexenyl acetate, 6-methyl-5-hepten-2-one, and (E)-2-hexenal in wheat stem sawfly-infested smooth brome, and elevated production of 6-methyl-5-hepten-2-one in infested smooth brome and winter wheat when compared to their uninfested counterparts. Both B. cephi and B. lissogaster exhibited significant electrophysiological and behavioral response to (Z)-3-hexenyl acetate, 6-methyl-5-hepten-2-one, and hexahydrofarnesyl acetone. Our results provide important evidence supporting habitat management recommendations that will enhance the effectiveness of biological control, contributing to more sustainable agricultural practices and the preservation of vital ecological functions.

title: LRES Graduate Student Organization
text:
LRES GSO Website 
What does the GSO do?:
The Land Resources and Environmental Science Graduate Student Organization (LRES GSO) is a student-run group at Montana State University, working to provide social and professional networking opportunities for grad students in our department. LRES boasts a wide range of diversity, from plant scientists, to environmental microbiologists, to hydrologists, and the GSO is here to help students take advantage of the rich knowledge base that this broad range of interests encompasses.
My roles:


2022‚Äì2023: Treasurer


2023‚Äì2025: Co-Chair


2025‚Äì2026: Treasurer


GSO-hosted events:
LEPS 2025
2024 LRES-PSPP Student Research Symposium
2023 LRES GSO Research Colloquium
2022 LRES Colloquium

title: Elk Park Exclosure Repair
text:
Weather



üå§Ô∏è Low 70s, sunny, light breeze. Perfect field day conditions.


David, Eric, and I went out to our Elk Park site to repair the exclosure that was a built a few years ago. A couple trees fell across the fencing into and across the exclosure.
Site activities:

Clear debris and remove downed trees from the exclosure
Remove damaged cattle panels and extract existing fence posts
Expand the existing monitoring grid to 10‚ÄØm √ó 10‚ÄØm and add road hairs
Construct new exclosure using fence posts, intact cattle panels, and new materials
Retrieve data from data loggers at the exclosure and control grid
Install game cameras at both the exclosure and control grid






Exclosure damage prior to repair






Toadflax in damaged exclosure






Jackson chainsawing logs in damaged exclosure






Jackson chainsawing while David looks on






Exclosure grid trail camera






Control grid trail camera

title: Elk Park and Badger Gulch - June 2025
text:
Weather



‚õÖ Mid 80ss, mostly sunny. Started to get real toasty as the day went on.
Eric and I drove out to Elk Park and Badger Gulch to retrieve trail camera images and release Rhinusa pilosa in both the control and exclosure grids at both sites. We planned to release at Hog Hollow as well but the gate leading to the site was locked. I am going to go back out tomorrow morning and meet up with our Forest Service contact to get through the gate.

title: Toadflax Biocontrol Field Notes
text:
Yellow (Linaria vulgaris) and Dalmatian (L. dalmatica) toadflax are invasive plants from Europe that have spread widely across rangelands in the western United States. They form dense patches that crowd out native vegetation, reduce forage for livestock and wildlife, and are difficult or costly to control with herbicides or mechanical methods. To address these challenges, researchers are exploring a range of strategies to limit their spread. My project focuses on biological control ‚Äî using insects that naturally feed on toadflax ‚Äî as a sustainable approach to long-term management.
I am currently working with three non-native weevil species: Mecinus janthinus, M. janthiniformis, and Rhinusa pilosa. The two Mecinus species attack toadflax by laying their eggs inside the stems; the developing larvae feed as they tunnel through the plant. Rhinusa pilosa works a little differently ‚Äî it lays its eggs in the stem and triggers the plant to form a gall, a swollen growth that provides food and protection for the larvae.



Site Locations

text:
I presented this talk at the 2024 Entomological Society of America (ESA) Annual Meeting in Phoenix, AZ. The presentation focused on the role of smooth brome in enhancing biological control of wheat stem sawfly through its support of native braconid parasitoid populations‚Äîemphasizing the potential for non-crop vegetation in agroecological management.

title: Jackson Strand

     ResearchGate
  

  
  
Jackson R. Strand I am a PhD student in Ecology and Environmental Sciences at Montana State University, where I study applied entomology and invasive plant management. My research focuses on the biological control of yellow and Dalmatian toadflax in Montana and South Dakota, using insect agents to support sustainable management and ecosystem restoration.
 M.S. in Entomology, Montana State University
B.S. in Biology, University of Minnesota

title: Jackson Strand
text:
Research Interests
I am interested in understanding the ecological roles of insects and their potential to address pressing global challenges, including improving agricultural productivity, combating climate change, and advancing waste management strategies. Through my research, I seek to develop innovative, nature-based solutions to these complex problems, focusing on the intersection of entomology, ecology, and sustainability.





My Master‚Äôs thesis with Dr.¬†David Weaver at Montana State University focused on the agroecological role of smooth brome grass in managing wheat stem sawfly (WSS) populations. Specifically, I investigated how smooth brome found along roadways and in coulees could reduce WSS larvae and provide a refuge for parasitoids Bracon cephi and B. lissogaster. Using a combination of volatile organic compound (VOC) analysis and field observations, I demonstrated that smooth brome, when found growing adjacent to wheat fields, could reduce WSS survival and support second-generation parasitoids. Please see my thesis or my thesis defense recording for more information.









My current PhD project with Dr.¬†Robert Peterson at Montana State University is investigating the efficacy of the weevil Rhinusa pilosa for the biological control of invasive yellow toadflax (Linaria vulgaris) in Montana and South Dakota. Specifically, I am interested in the ecological impacts of megaherbivores, parastioids, and climatic shifts on the establishment of beneficial R. pilosa populations.



 PhD Field Notes

My project focuses on biological control ‚Äî using insects that naturally feed on toadflax ‚Äî as a sustainable approach to long-term management.
I am currently working with three non-native weevil species: Mecinus janthinus, M. janthiniformis, and Rhinusa pilosa. They form dense patches that crowd out native vegetation, reduce forage for livestock and wildlife, and are difficult or costly to control with herbicides or mechanical methods. To address these challenges, researchers are exploring a range of strategies to limit their spread. My project focuses on biological control ‚Äî using insects that naturally feed on toadflax ‚Äî as a sustainable approach to long-term management.
I am currently working with three non-native weevil species: Mecinus janthinus, M. janthiniformis, and Rhinusa pilosa. title: Toadflax Biocontrol Field Notes
text:
Yellow (Linaria vulgaris) and Dalmatian (L. dalmatica) toadflax are invasive plants from Europe that have spread widely across rangelands in the western United States. They form dense patches that crowd out native vegetation, reduce forage for livestock and wildlife, and are difficult or costly to control with herbicides or mechanical methods. To address these challenges, researchers are exploring a range of strategies to limit their spread. My project focuses on biological control ‚Äî using insects that naturally feed on toadflax ‚Äî as a sustainable approach to long-term management.
I am currently working with three non-native weevil species: Mecinus janthinus, M. janthiniformis, and Rhinusa pilosa. The two Mecinus species attack toadflax by laying their eggs inside the stems; the developing larvae feed as they tunnel through the plant. Rhinusa pilosa works a little differently ‚Äî it lays its eggs in the stem and triggers the plant to form a gall, a swollen growth that provides food and protection for the larvae.

title: Research
text:
Beneficial insects play a crucial role in maintaining healthy ecosystems and supporting agriculture. They act as natural pollinators, predators, and decomposers, helping to control pest populations, enhance plant reproduction, and recycle nutrients. By reducing the need for human-derived inputs and chemical pesticides, these insects promote biodiversity, protect soil and water quality, and contribute to sustainable food production. Beneficial insects are essential allies in both natural and managed environments, quietly sustaining life and ecological balance.



For my PhD at Montana State University, I‚Äôm studying how to better manage invasive toadflax species that spread across rangelands in the western United States. These weeds, yellow toadflax (Linaria vulgaris) and Dalmatian toadflax (L. dalmatica), reduce forage for livestock, crowd out native plants, and are difficult to control with traditional methods.
My research focuses on using beneficial insects‚Äîspecifically two stem-mining weevils (Mecinus janthinus and M. janthiniformis) and a stem-galling weevil (Rhinusa pilosa) ‚Äî to help reduce toadflax populations. I‚Äôm combining field studies in Montana and South Dakota with long-term monitoring to see how these insects establish, reproduce, and affect the plants over time. I‚Äôm also interested in how events like wildfire and grazing by large animals shape the success of biocontrol.
Ultimately, this work will help improve regional weed management programs and provide new insights into how insects and invasive plants interact in different climates and under different disturbances.












For my Master‚Äôs research at Montana State University, I studied how smooth brome grass (Bromus inermis) supports two beneficial wasps, Bracon cephi and Bracon lissogaster, which parasitize and help control the wheat stem sawfly (Cephus cinctus), a major pest of cereal crops. At field sites in Bozeman, Big Sandy, and Moccasin, Montana, I found that smooth brome provides a critical late-season refuge for these wasps. This refuge is especially important in years with early wheat harvests, drought, or fire, when wheat may be removed. By providing alternative host plants for the wasps, smooth brome helps sustain their populations even when wheat stem sawfly hosts are scarce, preventing major declines and keeping pest numbers in check over time.









 Read Strand et al.¬†2024

title: Research
text:
My on-going research at Montana State University for my PhD focuses on the biological control of invasive toadflax species found within rangelands of the western United States. Specifically, I am investigating the use of specialist Eurasian herbivores to suppress populations of yellow (Linaria vulgaris) and Dalmatian (L. dalmatica) toadflax in Montana and South Dakota. I am currently working with the two stem mining weevils Mecinus janthinus, M. janthiniformis, and the stem-galling weevil Rhinusa pilosa. My work combines classical biocontrol approaches with life table analyses and fire ecology to understand the long-term population dynamics of both plants and insects.











Yellow toadflax is perennial invasive weeds that reduce forage quality, compete with native vegetation, and resist many conventional management strategies. My current research focuses on evaluating the efficacy of the stem-galling weevil Rhinusa pilosa in controlling yellow toadflax popuulations. Using monitoring plots in Montana and South Dakota, I hope to track R. pilosa establishment, reproduction, and impact across multiple years. In addition, I‚Äôm interested in the impact of large herbivores on both toadflax and biocontrol persistence. These data will support regional biocontrol programs and provide new insights into the suitability of R. pilosa in different climates and disturbance regimes.



As part of a broader interest in weed biocontrol, I also assist in the study of Tamarix spp. (salt cedar), an invasive woody shrub of riparian systems in the western U.S. Salt cedar biocontrol, particularly using the leaf beetle Diorhabda spp., provides a useful comparative system for understanding the successes and challenges of long-term weed management with insects. My focus here is on lessons from Diorhabda‚ÄìTamarix interactions that can inform biocontrol strategies for toadflax, particularly regarding climate adaptation, dispersal, and non-target concerns.

title: Research
text:
Chemical Ecology of Beneficial Insects
My work also explores how plant chemistry mediates the interactions between insect herbivores, their natural enemies, and their host plants. I use a combination of volatile collections, electrophysiological assays (EAG/EAD-FID), and behavioral bioassays to identify compounds that structure ecological interactions and drive host specificity.

Wheat stem sawfly parasitoids
During my M.S. research at MSU, I investigated the role of smooth brome (Bromus inermis) as a refuge habitat for parasitoids of the wheat stem sawfly (Cephus cinctus). Using volatile organic compound (VOC) collections, I examined whether smooth brome emits chemical cues that parasitoids use to locate hosts. My findings showed that parasitoids readily colonize brome-dominated field margins, enhancing biological control within wheat fields and highlighting the agroecological value of seminatural habitats.


Mecinus janthinus and M. janthiniformis
As part of my PhD, I am studying the host-location behavior of the stem-mining weevils Mecinus janthinus (yellow toadflax specialist) and M. janthiniformis (Dalmatian toadflax specialist). Using Y-tube olfactometer assays, we demonstrated that female M. janthiniformis are attracted to volatiles from both yellow and Dalmatian toadflax, while M. janthinus responds only to yellow toadflax. I am coupling these behavioral assays with EAG-FID to identify plant compounds eliciting antennal responses, with the goal of linking specific VOCs to insect host fidelity and biocontrol effectiveness.

title: Research
text:
My on-going research at Montana State University for my PhD focuses on the biological control of invasive toadflax species found within rangelands of the western United States. Specifically, I am investigating the use of specialist Eurasian herbivores to suppress populations of yellow (Linaria vulgaris) and Dalmatian (L. dalmatica) toadflax in Montana and South Dakota. I am currently working with the two stem mining weevils Mecinus janthinus, M. janthiniformis, and the stem-galling weevil Rhinusa pilosa. My work combines classical biocontrol approaches with life table analyses and fire ecology to understand the long-term population dynamics of both plants and insects.











Yellow toadflax is perennial invasive weeds that reduce forage quality, compete with native vegetation, and resist many conventional management strategies. My current research focuses on evaluating the efficacy of the stem-galling weevil Rhinusa pilosa in controlling yellow toadflax popuulations. Using monitoring plots in Montana and South Dakota, I hope to track R. pilosa establishment, reproduction, and impact across multiple years. In addition, I‚Äôm interested in the impact of large herbivores on both toadflax and biocontrol persistence. These data will support regional biocontrol programs and provide new insights into the suitability of R. pilosa in different climates and disturbance regimes.






As part of a broader interest in weed biocontrol, I also assist in the study of Tamarix spp. (salt cedar), an invasive woody shrub of riparian systems in the western U.S. Salt cedar biocontrol, particularly using the leaf beetle Diorhabda spp., provides a useful comparative system for understanding the successes and challenges of long-term weed management with insects. My focus here is on lessons from Diorhabda‚ÄìTamarix interactions that can inform biocontrol strategies for toadflax, particularly regarding climate adaptation, dispersal, and non-target concerns.

title: Research
text:
Beneficial insects play a crucial role in maintaining healthy ecosystems and supporting agriculture. They act as natural pollinators, predators, and decomposers, helping to control pest populations, enhance plant reproduction, and recycle nutrients. By reducing the need for human-derived inputs and chemical pesticides, these insects promote biodiversity, protect soil and water quality, and contribute to sustainable food production. In short, beneficial insects are essential allies in both natural and managed environments, quietly sustaining life and ecological balance.
My on-going PhD project at Montana State University focuses on the biological control of invasive toadflax species found within rangelands of the western United States. Specifically, I am investigating the use of the two stem mining weevils Mecinus janthinus, M. janthiniformis, and the stem-galling weevil Rhinusa pilosa to suppress populations of yellow (Linaria vulgaris) and Dalmatian (L. dalmatica) toadflax in Montana and South Dakota. My work combines classical biocontrol approaches with life table analyses and fire ecology to understand the long-term population dynamics of both plants and insects.











Yellow toadflax is perennial invasive weeds that reduce forage quality, compete with native vegetation, and resist many conventional management strategies. My current research focuses on evaluating the efficacy of the stem-galling weevil Rhinusa pilosa in controlling yellow toadflax popuulations. Using monitoring plots in Montana and South Dakota, I hope to track R. pilosa establishment, reproduction, and impact across multiple years. In addition, I‚Äôm interested in the impact of large herbivores on both toadflax and biocontrol persistence. These data will support regional biocontrol programs and provide new insights into the suitability of R. pilosa in different climates and disturbance regimes.






As part of a broader interest in weed biocontrol, I also assist in the study of Tamarix spp. (salt cedar), an invasive woody shrub of riparian systems in the western U.S. Salt cedar biocontrol, particularly using the leaf beetle Diorhabda spp., provides a useful comparative system for understanding the successes and challenges of long-term weed management with insects. My focus here is on lessons from Diorhabda‚ÄìTamarix interactions that can inform biocontrol strategies for toadflax, particularly regarding climate adaptation, dispersal, and non-target concerns.

title: Research
text:
Chemical Ecology of Plant-Insect Interactions

My research also looks at how plant chemistry influences interactions between insects, their natural enemies, and the plants they feed on. Plants release chemical signals called volatile organic compounds (VOCs), which are essentially scents that can travel through the air. These VOCs play a key role in ecosystems because they can attract or repel insects, signal danger, or guide predators and parasitoids to their prey.
To understand these interactions, I collect plant volatiles and study how insects respond to them using electrophysiological techniques (which measure how insect antennae detect these chemicals) and behavioral tests. By identifying the specific compounds that insects respond to, I can uncover how plant chemistry shapes feeding behavior, host choice, and the relationships between plants, herbivores, and their natural enemies.











Mecinus janthinus and M. janthiniformis
As part of my PhD, I am studying the host-location behavior of the stem-mining weevils Mecinus janthinus (yellow toadflax specialist) and M. janthiniformis (Dalmatian toadflax specialist). Using Y-tube olfactometer assays, we demonstrated that female M. janthiniformis are attracted to volatiles from both yellow and Dalmatian toadflax, while M. janthinus responds only to yellow toadflax. I am coupling these behavioral assays with EAG-FID to identify plant compounds eliciting antennal responses, with the goal of linking specific VOCs to insect host fidelity and biocontrol effectiveness.

Salt Cedar Biological Control
As part of a broader interest in weed biocontrol, I also assist in the study of Tamarix spp. (salt cedar), an invasive woody shrub of riparian systems in the western U.S. Salt cedar biocontrol, particularly using the leaf beetle Diorhabda spp., provides a useful comparative system for understanding the successes and challenges of long-term weed management with insects. My focus here is on lessons from Diorhabda‚ÄìTamarix interactions that can inform biocontrol strategies for toadflax, particularly regarding climate adaptation, dispersal, and non-target concerns.

title: Research
text:
Beneficial insects play a crucial role in maintaining healthy ecosystems and supporting agriculture. They act as natural pollinators, predators, and decomposers, helping to control pest populations, enhance plant reproduction, and recycle nutrients. By reducing the need for human-derived inputs and chemical pesticides, these insects promote biodiversity, protect soil and water quality, and contribute to sustainable food production. Beneficial insects are essential allies in both natural and managed environments, quietly sustaining life and ecological balance.



For my PhD at Montana State University, I‚Äôm studying how to better manage invasive toadflax species that spread across rangelands in the western United States. These weeds, yellow toadflax (Linaria vulgaris) and Dalmatian toadflax (L. dalmatica), reduce forage for livestock, crowd out native plants, and are difficult to control with traditional methods.
My research focuses on using beneficial insects‚Äîspecifically two stem-mining weevils (Mecinus janthinus and M. janthiniformis) and a stem-galling weevil (Rhinusa pilosa) ‚Äî to help reduce toadflax populations. I‚Äôm combining field studies in Montana and South Dakota with long-term monitoring to see how these insects establish, reproduce, and affect the plants over time. I‚Äôm also interested in how events like wildfire and grazing by large animals shape the success of biocontrol.
Ultimately, this work will help improve regional weed management programs and provide new insights into how insects and invasive plants interact in different climates and under different disturbances.












For my Master‚Äôs research at Montana State University, I studied how smooth brome grass (Bromus inermis) supports two beneficial wasps, Bracon cephi and Bracon lissogaster, which parasitize and help control the wheat stem sawfly (Cephus cinctus), a major pest of cereal crops. At field sites in Bozeman, Big Sandy, and Moccasin, Montana, I found that smooth brome provides a critical late-season refuge for these wasps. This refuge is especially important in years with early wheat harvests, drought, or fire, when wheat may be removed. By providing alternative host plants for the wasps, smooth brome helps sustain their populations even when wheat stem sawfly hosts are scarce, preventing major declines and keeping pest numbers in check over time.
